DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mostly lower in thin trading in Europe late this morning, and dealers predicted it will move only slightly throughout the day as most investors have concluded their currency transactions for the year. Gold prices also fell. Traders said a year-end holiday spirit has settled over the market, giving little incentive to take positions or launch new initiatives. They cautioned that the market could be vulnerable to sharp swings due to the thinness of trading, but they predicted most major currencies would hold to narrow ranges before the end of the year. ``We've pretty much finished any major movements,'' said one trader in Milan, Italy. ``This is a classic year-end market. Just as the summer market usually shows a stronger dollar, the winter market shows a weaker dollar.'' A dealer at a U.S. bank in Frankfurt agreed: ``Most of the players closed their books Friday and have withdrawn from the market. We are also effectively finished for the year. There is no more interest; it is typical for Christmas.'' In Toyko, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell slightly against the Japanese yen, closing at 144.22 yen, down 0.08 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 144.26 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Friday: _1.7218 West German marks, down from 1.7225 _1.5456 Swiss francs, down from 1.5485 _5.8825 French francs, down from 5.8885 _1.9415 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9480 _1,285.50 Italian lire, down from 1,286.50 _1.1609 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1606 In London, the dollar rose marginally against the British pound. It cost $1.6053 to buy one pound, compared with $1.6055 late Friday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $412.75 a troy ounce, up from $412.25 bid late Friday. At midmorning, the city's five major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $411.65. In Zurich, the bid price was $410.70, down from $412.50 bid late Friday. Gold in Hong Kong fell $2.10 to close at a bid $410.97. Silver slipped in London to a bid price of $5.61 a troy ounce from Friday's $5.62.
